title: China donates a Voltage Transformer to Equatorial Guinea
description: In November 2009, an agreement was signed between the Chinese Ambassador and Guinea's Foreign Minister for the donation of a transformer to the Bata Ministry of Foreign Affairs building. The monetary value of the equipment is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China donates a Voltage Transformer to Equatorial Guinea

# Description
In November 2009, an agreement was signed between the Chinese Ambassador and Guinea's Foreign Minister for the donation of a transformer to the Bata Ministry of Foreign Affairs building. The monetary value of the equipment is unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of electrical equipment for a government building, with no clear energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of voltage transformer to government building, no energy generation or transmission context provided

title: China sends agricultural experts to Equatorial Guinea
description: On July 25, 2009, 6 agricultural experts and 2 interpreters arrived in Malabo for one year consultation on agricultural policy, livestock husbandry, and aquaculture.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China sends agricultural experts to Equatorial Guinea

# Description
On July 25, 2009, 6 agricultural experts and 2 interpreters arrived in Malabo for one year consultation on agricultural policy, livestock husbandry, and aquaculture.
justification: Project focuses on knowledge transfer and capacity building in agriculture without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Agricultural experts providing consultation on policy, livestock, and aquaculture

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Malabo Primary School Construction Project
description: In 2009, China’s Ministry of Commerce provided a grant to the Government of Equatorial Guinea for the Malabo Primary School Construction Project. This project involved the construction of a primary school in the city of Malabo, which also goes by the China-Equatorial Guinea Friendship Primary School.  China Dalian International Cooperation Group was the contractor responsible for project implementation and China Youfa International Engineering was the contractor responsible for project supervision. Construction began on April 20, 2009 and was scheduled to end on October 20, 2009. Construction was ultimately completed in mid-December 2009. The project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities in Equatorial Guinea on July 22, 2010.  Then, on December 12, 2012, the Chinese Ambassador to Equatorial Guinea visited the school.
staff_comments: This project is distinct from ProjectID#32426, which involved construction of a primary school in Bata.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Malabo Primary School Construction Project

# Description
In 2009, China’s Ministry of Commerce provided a grant to the Government of Equatorial Guinea for the Malabo Primary School Construction Project. This project involved the construction of a primary school in the city of Malabo, which also goes by the China-Equatorial Guinea Friendship Primary School.  China Dalian International Cooperation Group was the contractor responsible for project implementation and China Youfa International Engineering was the contractor responsible for project supervision. Construction began on April 20, 2009 and was scheduled to end on October 20, 2009. Construction was ultimately completed in mid-December 2009. The project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities in Equatorial Guinea on July 22, 2010.  Then, on December 12, 2012, the Chinese Ambassador to Equatorial Guinea visited the school.
justification: Project is focused on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Primary school construction, education sector focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides grant for establishment of anti-malaria center at Bata General Hospital
description: On June 7, 2009 the opening ceremony for a Chinese Government-funded anti-malaria center was held in Bata, Equatorial Guinea. The project is also referred to as a Diseases Prevention and Control Center. The anti-malaria center is housed within the General Hospital of Bata. The Zhejiang Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention implemented the project, and the Chinese Government provided equipment and medicines.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for establishment of anti-malaria center at Bata General Hospital

# Description
On June 7, 2009 the opening ceremony for a Chinese Government-funded anti-malaria center was held in Bata, Equatorial Guinea. The project is also referred to as a Diseases Prevention and Control Center. The anti-malaria center is housed within the General Hospital of Bata. The Zhejiang Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention implemented the project, and the Chinese Government provided equipment and medicines.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-malaria center, healthcare focus, disease prevention and control

title: China Eximbank provide $549.95 million buyer’s credit loan for Djibloho Power Transmission and Transformation Project (Linked to Project ID#995, #62127, #484)
description: In 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility agreement for various infrastructure projects (captured in Project ID#484). All subsidiary loans approved under this facility agreement carry the following terms: a 5.5% interest rate, a 5 year maturity, and a 2 year grace period.  Then, in 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a subsidiary buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Djibloho Power Transmission and Transformation Project. The proceeds of the loan were used by the borrower to finance a $647 million commercial (EPC) contract with China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC). The estimated face value of loan is $549.95 million (since other subsidiary buyer’s credit loans that were approved through the $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility were use to finance 85% of commercial contract costs).  The purpose of this project was to evacuate power from the China Eximbank-financed 120MW Djibloho Hydropower Station (captured in Project ID#995) to 25 cities in mainland Equatorial Guinea. It involved the construction of 1,366 km of power transmission lines; the construction of twenty-six, 5200 kV, 13110kV, and 820kV substations; and the construction of 1 national control (dispatch) center.  CMEC and one of its subsidiaries (CMEC Comtrans International Co., Ltd.) were responsible for implementation. A groundbreaking ceremony for the project was held on June 21, 2009. Another major milestone was achieved on December 28, 2011 when the South Akure Sub-station and Mengomeyén Sub-station achieved synchronized power transmission. A project completion ceremony was held on October 10, 2012.  This project is closely related to two other China Eximbank-financed projects: the 120MW Djibloho Hydropower Station Project (captured via Project ID#995) and the Djibloho Regulating Reservoir Project (captured via Project ID#62127).
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Djiploho Power Transmission and Transformation Project or the Giblau Power Transmission and Transformation Project. 2. The Chinese project title is 赤道几内亚吉布劳水电站 or 赤道几内亚吉布劳输变电线路一期、二期项目 or 赤道几内亚吉布劳水电站输变电线路工程项目. 3. Neither Boston University's Global Development Policy Center nor SAIS-CARI record the China Eximbank loan for this project.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provide $549.95 million buyer’s credit loan for Djibloho Power Transmission and Transformation Project (Linked to Project ID#995, #62127, #484)

# Description
In 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility agreement for various infrastructure projects (captured in Project ID#484). All subsidiary loans approved under this facility agreement carry the following terms: a 5.5% interest rate, a 5 year maturity, and a 2 year grace period.  Then, in 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a subsidiary buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Djibloho Power Transmission and Transformation Project. The proceeds of the loan were used by the borrower to finance a $647 million commercial (EPC) contract with China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC). The estimated face value of loan is $549.95 million (since other subsidiary buyer’s credit loans that were approved through the $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility were use to finance 85% of commercial contract costs).  The purpose of this project was to evacuate power from the China Eximbank-financed 120MW Djibloho Hydropower Station (captured in Project ID#995) to 25 cities in mainland Equatorial Guinea. It involved the construction of 1,366 km of power transmission lines; the construction of twenty-six, 5200 kV, 13110kV, and 820kV substations; and the construction of 1 national control (dispatch) center.  CMEC and one of its subsidiaries (CMEC Comtrans International Co., Ltd.) were responsible for implementation. A groundbreaking ceremony for the project was held on June 21, 2009. Another major milestone was achieved on December 28, 2011 when the South Akure Sub-station and Mengomeyén Sub-station achieved synchronized power transmission. A project completion ceremony was held on October 10, 2012.  This project is closely related to two other China Eximbank-financed projects: the 120MW Djibloho Hydropower Station Project (captured via Project ID#995) and the Djibloho Regulating Reservoir Project (captured via Project ID#62127).
justification: Primary purpose is power transmission and transformation infrastructure, enabling renewable energy distribution but not directly generating clean energy
evidence: Construction of 1,366 km power transmission lines, multiple substations, and national control center for evacuating power from hydropower station

title: CGGC provides RMB 2.8577 billion supplier’s credit for Malabo Sewage Treatment Plant and Sewage Pipe Network Project
description: In 2009, China Gezhouba Group Corporation (CGGC) and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a supplier’s credit agreement for the Malabo Sewage Treatment Project. The estimated value of the supplier’s credit (loan) is RMB 2.8577 billion (EUR 270.3 million). In order to finance its supplier’s credit agreement with the Government of Equatorial Guinea, CGGC secured one or more export seller’s credits from China Eximbank. The proceeds of the supplier’s credit were to be used by the borrower to finance approximately 85% of the cost of an RMB 3.362 billion (EUR 318 million) commercial (EPC) contract between the Government of Equatorial Guinea and CGGC, which was signed on February 24, 2008. The borrowing terms of the supplier’s credit are unknown. However, it is known that the supplier’s credit was backed by a Sinosure credit insurance policy, which was finalized in September 2013 and provided $119 million of coverage.   The project involved the (1) the construction of a sewage treatment plant in Malabo (with the capacity of 40,000 cubic meters of sewage and the ability to treat and discharge 10,000-14,000 cubic meters of sewage per day), and (2) construction of a 238 km (or 239.5 km) network of sewage pipes in Malabo. These two project components are known as Phase 1 and Phase 2, respectively. The project also involved the installation of 5 sewage pumping stations. However, it is unclear if this component was undertaken as part of Phase 1 or Phase 2. Upon completion, this project was expected to benefit 100,000 local residents of Malabo.    CGGC was the general EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. However, Long Jian Road and Bridge Co., Ltd., SCEGC Installation Group Company Ltd., CMEC Comtrans International Co., Ltd., and Anhu Shui'an Construction Group Co., Ltd. were also involved in implementation. Phase 1 took place between August 18, 2008 and August 2012. Phase 2 commenced on June 13, 2013. The Malabo sewage treatment plant and sewage pipe network entered its trial operation period on October 8, 2015. It was officially handed over to the local authorities in 2019. The Malabo sewage treatment plant and sewage pipe network reportedly now collects 14,000 cubic meters of municipal sewage each day (on average) and provide 85% to 90% of the city’s sewage treatment capacity.   However, this project also faced significant implementation and debt repayment challenges. Sinosure made an EUR 6.53 million indemnity payment to CGGC in December 2014 due to the fact that the Government of Equatorial Guinea defaulted on its payment obligations to CGGC. Then, in September 2017, Sinosure made another EUR 3.25 million indemnity payment to CGGC for the same reason.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Malabo Wastewater and Rainwater Treatment Plant Project and the Malabo City Sewage Pipe Network and Sewage Treatment Plant Projec. The Chinese project title is 都马拉博城市污水管网与污水处理厂项目 or 马拉博城市污水管网与污水处理厂项目 or 赤道几内亚马拉博城市污水管网及污水处理厂工程 or 赤道几内亚马拉博市污水和雨水处理及管网系统工程 or 赤道几内亚马拉博城市污水管网工程 or 赤道几内亚马拉博城市污水管网及处理厂项目. The Spanish project title is Construccion del sistema de red de canalizacion y tratamiento de aguas residuales y pluviales de la Ciudad de Malabo or Proyecto de Construccion del sistema de red de canalizacion y tratamiento de aguas residuales y pluviales de la Ciudad de Malabo. 2. SAIS-CARI and Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center record a $132 million (RMB 900 million) supplier’s credit from CGGC for this project. However, given that the project was implemented in two phases and the total cost of the commercial contract for both phases was RMB 2.8577 billion (EUR 270.3 million), their estimate appears to only capture the financial commitment for phase 1 (which is also recorded by China Eximbank as RMB 900 million). This source (https://www.dropbox.com/s/vtf55ft7x7qetik/%E6%94%BF%E7%AD%96%E6%80%A7%E9%93%B6%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%B9%E9%9D%A9%E7%9A%84%E4%B8%BB%E8%A6%81%E6%96%B9%E5%90%91%28%E6%94%BF%E7%AD%96%E6%80%A7%E9%93%B6%E8%A1%8C%E5%92%8C%E5%95%86%E4%B8%9A%E9%93%B6%E8%A1%8C%E7%9A%84%E4%B8%BB%E8%A6%81%E8%81%94%E7%B3%BB%29-%E6%96%B0%E4%BB%94seo.pdf?dl=0) indicates that China Eximbank supported the project’s first phase and second phase. 3. In June 2012, the Government of Equatorial Guinea and CGGC signed a commercial contract for Phase 2 (involving the construction of 238 km of sewage pipes in Malabo). It is unclear if this contract represents an amendment of the February 24, 2008. This issue warrants additional investigation.4. In September 2013, CGGC purchased a $119 million credit insurance policy from Sinosure in support of the June 2012 contract that it signed for Phase 2.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
CGGC provides RMB 2.8577 billion supplier’s credit for Malabo Sewage Treatment Plant and Sewage Pipe Network Project

# Description
In 2009, China Gezhouba Group Corporation (CGGC) and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a supplier’s credit agreement for the Malabo Sewage Treatment Project. The estimated value of the supplier’s credit (loan) is RMB 2.8577 billion (EUR 270.3 million). In order to finance its supplier’s credit agreement with the Government of Equatorial Guinea, CGGC secured one or more export seller’s credits from China Eximbank. The proceeds of the supplier’s credit were to be used by the borrower to finance approximately 85% of the cost of an RMB 3.362 billion (EUR 318 million) commercial (EPC) contract between the Government of Equatorial Guinea and CGGC, which was signed on February 24, 2008. The borrowing terms of the supplier’s credit are unknown. However, it is known that the supplier’s credit was backed by a Sinosure credit insurance policy, which was finalized in September 2013 and provided $119 million of coverage.   The project involved the (1) the construction of a sewage treatment plant in Malabo (with the capacity of 40,000 cubic meters of sewage and the ability to treat and discharge 10,000-14,000 cubic meters of sewage per day), and (2) construction of a 238 km (or 239.5 km) network of sewage pipes in Malabo. These two project components are known as Phase 1 and Phase 2, respectively. The project also involved the installation of 5 sewage pumping stations. However, it is unclear if this component was undertaken as part of Phase 1 or Phase 2. Upon completion, this project was expected to benefit 100,000 local residents of Malabo.    CGGC was the general EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. However, Long Jian Road and Bridge Co., Ltd., SCEGC Installation Group Company Ltd., CMEC Comtrans International Co., Ltd., and Anhu Shui'an Construction Group Co., Ltd. were also involved in implementation. Phase 1 took place between August 18, 2008 and August 2012. Phase 2 commenced on June 13, 2013. The Malabo sewage treatment plant and sewage pipe network entered its trial operation period on October 8, 2015. It was officially handed over to the local authorities in 2019. The Malabo sewage treatment plant and sewage pipe network reportedly now collects 14,000 cubic meters of municipal sewage each day (on average) and provide 85% to 90% of the city’s sewage treatment capacity.   However, this project also faced significant implementation and debt repayment challenges. Sinosure made an EUR 6.53 million indemnity payment to CGGC in December 2014 due to the fact that the Government of Equatorial Guinea defaulted on its payment obligations to CGGC. Then, in September 2017, Sinosure made another EUR 3.25 million indemnity payment to CGGC for the same reason.
justification: Project focuses on water supply and sanitation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of sewage treatment plant and sewage pipe network, primarily aimed at improving sanitation services

title: China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation donates office supplies valued $50,000 and 200 footballs to Equatorial Guinean government (Link to #67054)
description: On February 23, 2009, China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation and China National Petroleum Corporation held a donation ceremony for the donation of office supplies to Equatorial Guinea's Ministry of Mines and Mines. China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation donated office supplies valued $50,000 to the Ministry of Industry and Energy and 200 footballs to the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Craft Promotion.  China National Petroleum Corporation joined the same donation ceremony see the project ID: #67054
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation donates office supplies valued $50,000 and 200 footballs to Equatorial Guinean government (Link to #67054)

# Description
On February 23, 2009, China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation and China National Petroleum Corporation held a donation ceremony for the donation of office supplies to Equatorial Guinea's Ministry of Mines and Mines. China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation donated office supplies valued $50,000 to the Ministry of Industry and Energy and 200 footballs to the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Craft Promotion.  China National Petroleum Corporation joined the same donation ceremony see the project ID: #67054
justification: Project involves donation of office supplies and sports equipment with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of office supplies and footballs to government ministries, no energy-related components

title: CNOOC donates 5 generators to Equatorial Guinea Ministry of Health
description: On March 3, 2009, Gao Zhifeng, Commercial Counsellor of the Embassy of the People's Republic of China in the Republic of Equatorial Guinea, attended the donation ceremony of 5 generators to the hospital of the Equatorial Guinean Ministry of Health by China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC).

title: CGGC builds four wells in Malabo (linked to #72034)
description: In December 2009, China Gezhouba Group Company Ltd. (CGGC) donated four wells in residential and commercial areas of Malabo. CGGC built and equipped the four wells. A completion ceremony for the wells was held on April 5, 2010. According to MOFCOM, the four wells were worth $700,000.  According to SASAC, CGGC donated a fifth well in 2011. No information about its monetary value has been identified. That donation is captured by Project ID#72034.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
CGGC builds four wells in Malabo (linked to #72034)

# Description
In December 2009, China Gezhouba Group Company Ltd. (CGGC) donated four wells in residential and commercial areas of Malabo. CGGC built and equipped the four wells. A completion ceremony for the wells was held on April 5, 2010. According to MOFCOM, the four wells were worth $700,000.  According to SASAC, CGGC donated a fifth well in 2011. No information about its monetary value has been identified. That donation is captured by Project ID#72034.
justification: Water supply project primarily focused on social development and basic infrastructure
evidence: Construction of wells in residential and commercial areas, focus on water supply and sanitation
